summary_points: 1. Sherwin-Williams completed two acquisitions in 2024: a metal packaging coatings business for approximately $80 million and a European coil and industrial coatings company (closing in 2025).
2.  In 2025, Sherwin-Williams projects a $40 million increase in interest expense due to higher interest rates and new headquarters costs.
3.  Sherwin-Williams anticipates a low-single-digit percentage increase in raw material and employee-related costs in 2025.
1. Booking Holdings' net income significantly increased by $1,593 million year-over-year to $5,882 million in 2024.
2.  A €413 million ($530 million) fine was levied against Booking.com by the CNMC in Spain in 2024, prompting an appeal.
3. Booking Holdings anticipates lower operating income in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024, primarily due to Easter timing and unfavorable foreign exchange rates.
1. On February 20, 2025, Johnson & Johnson completed five public offerings of notes totaling $5 billion, with maturities ranging from 2027 to 2035 and interest rates from 4.5% to 5%.
2.  The offering of the 5.000% Notes due 2035 had the largest aggregate principal amount at $1,250,000,000.
3.  Johnson & Johnson intends to use the net proceeds from this debt offering, along with other funds, to finance its acquisition of Intra-Cellular Therapies, Inc.
1. On February 19, 2025, American International Group, Inc. (AIG) appointed Juan Perez, Salesforce's Executive Vice President and CIO, as an independent director, increasing the board size to 12.
2.  The SEC filing is an 8-K, indicating a current report, filed on February 20, 2025, regarding a material event.
3. Mr. Perez's compensation will follow the program outlined in AIG's 2024 proxy statement.
1. On February 20, 2025, HCA Healthcare, Inc. refinanced its $8 billion in senior secured credit facilities with an $8 billion senior unsecured revolving credit facility, maturing in five years.
2.  The outstanding balance on the senior secured credit facilities was $4.738 billion as of December 31, 2024, and these were fully repaid before being terminated.
3.  The new credit agreement includes a quarterly-tested financial covenant limiting the leverage ratio to 4.50:1.00, with a potential step-up to 5.00:1.00 following a material acquisition.
